>
> > Actually, the only claim that was made on this thread was that it  
> was
> > unprofessional *not* to do TDD all the time or to have less than  
> 90% code
> > coverage.

I'm quite happy to stand by that claim.  Over the last 7 years I have  
come to the following conclusions:

1. There are no instances in which TDD is impossible.
2. There are no instances in which TDD is not advantageous.
3. The impediments to TDD are human, not technical.
4. The alternative to TDD is code that is not repeatably testable.

Therefore I consider TDD to be a minimum professional standard.   
Developers who do not use TDD fall below that standard.
>
> > My follow-up claim is that anyone who says this has never really  
> worked on
> > the kind of real-world projects that I (and hundreds of thousands  
> of other
> > developers out there) are involved in on a daily basis.

I'm afraid I'm the counter example. I am nearly 54 years old and have  
been writing code since I was 15.  I still write code of one kind or  
another nearly every day.  I have worked on projects large and small,  
embedded and batch, system and application, in sickness and in heath,  
and I expect to code till I die.  Like Isaac Asimov used to say, I  
want them to find me with my nose jammed between the keys of my  
keyboard.

I'm afraid that there are also other counter examples.  I just got  
back from consulting with a team of 18 .NET developers working on a  
huge web-based application.  They have code coverage in the 90s, have  
unit tests and acceptance tests that are run every build.

Take a look at the Rails framework.  This is a web-development  
framework that has testing built in from the very start.  Virtually  
every facet of a rails application is intended to be written using  
TDD.  The point is that the new hyper-productive frameworks are  
adopting TDD from the get-go.

TDD is a fundamental change in the minute by minute process of  
writing software.  Many developers are not willing to face that  
change and look for reasons why TDD does not apply to them.  I  
believe that there are no such reasons.
